addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable my very singular good Lord the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England

19 Au
g
15
[9]
1 M
r
Bodeleie to my L
The continuance of
e
[states]
[...]
towardes
S
r
[Edward]
Norris
. Divers other matters.

page.lettertext:
fol.296r
May it please yo
r
good L. I have used towardes
Co
n
t Moryce
.
Count Maurice those gratulatorie complem
e
ts,
w
ch
her
Hig
nes
hath required, by yo
r
L. letter
of
e 25 of
e last, w
ch
I receaved at
Arnh
a
e 12 of this p
nt
: and there presented that
letter, w
ch
her Ma
tie
writte unto him. He ac-
cepted
it
of me very cheerefully, as a singular
token of her gratious favo
r
: and so he protested
w
t
his humblest thankes, and w
t
e offer of his
service in all occasions wheresoever. Because
his letter heerw
t
is an answear therunto, I re-
ferre my self to that w
ch
he himself hath signified.
To
e same effect as yo
r
L. hath writ-
M
r
Wyntar
ten in favo
r
of M
r
Winter, both
S
r
Francis Vere
and I were in hand w
t
e Count,
e next day
after that
e Enemie was defeated. And as
he promised then very willingly, so nowe againe
he assured me, that M
r
Winter shall have any
one or two of these prisoners, as he himself will
desire: and that none shall be redeemed, till
some order hath bin taken for his raunsome.
Alwaies provided, that consideration may be
had, for contenting of
e Captaines, by whome
these prisoners were taken. There
are but
three
of them remaining:
e rest are all de-
livered. But these are
e chiefest, and yet I
doubt
e Spaniardes will not give M
r
Winter
Alf
o
so Davalos
for them all. Heere is
Alfonso Davalos bastard
brother to
e
Marquis of Guasto
, who for ought we
can heare hath but a pension of a 1000 crowns
by
e yere, and his company of horse. He is
prisoner to one
Cap
t
Kintskie
.
The second
pedro fr
a
cesco
.
is
Don
Pedro Francesco
de Nicellj who is priso-
ner to Cap
t
B axes
and
Balle
. We can not
understand, that he hath any stay of living,
besides
e benefit of that cornet, wherof he was
fol.296v
Captaine, w
ch
was garde unto
e
Duke,
and hap-
pely some pay, for being general commaunder of
e horsmen of provision. The third is
Count
Co
n
t Decio
Decio
, who is prisoner to
S
r
John Pooley
, but a yonger
brother of those Countes of
Italy,
and as it
is thought, and affirmed by himself hath nothing
of his owne, but
e bare intertenment of a lieu-
tenant to
Hieronymo Caraffa
. The weal-
thiest among them all was one
Pradiglia
, who
padiglio dead
died in Arnham of his woundes. In effect I
have told M
r
Winters servant, that w
at
soever
usage w
t
reason, of those that are in custody,
may stand his master in steede, for his speedier
deliverance, I doe not doubt but
e Count will
willingly yelde unto it. And I will signifie
as muche to
e prisoners themselves, and gette
their letters to
Mondragon,
to cause M
r
Winter
to be better intreated. Wheras yo
r
L. doth require a description of
e places, where
any service is perfourmed, it is not possible ma-
ny times, but by naming of suche places as are
next adjoining: w
ch
I thought I had alwaies
sett downe sufficiently. For heere are many
Fortes in these contreis, aswell of
e Enemie, as
of o
rs
, and in
Groeninghen
especially, that have
bin made but of late, and are not expressed
in any Cart of
at contrey. And likewise
for
e plottes of growndes and formes of fightes,
of w
ch
yo
r
L. is desirous, unles it were so
at
e Councel were present in
e place of c
o
flict,
it can not be done very readily. For though
e
Councel
of state be often at
e campe, yet
their usual residence is at
e next and safest
towne: and there they are informed howe any
fol.297r
action doth passe, w
ch
is but summarily and
by letters on
e soddaine: w
ch
I doe certifie
presently in as ample sort, as
e intelligence is
given. And if I should attend
e returne of
some captaine, to describe every circumstance, it
would require a leasure time, and hinder her
Hig
nes
from speedy advertisment. There are
some men heere sometimes
at doe pourtraict suche
services, of w
ch
I will not faile to send yo
w
any
that can be gotten of o
r
later exploites: and for
mine owne part heereafter, to use all endevo
r
,
for expressing all thinges more particularly.
Moreover in any encounter or military action,
that ether one Nation above other, or speciall per-
ons above
e rest, shall shewe any valo
r
, to be
noted a part, I will not faile to report it,
as their service shall merit. But in
e late de-
feat of
e Enemies horse,
e most of o
r
troupes,
aswell of
e horsmen as footmen, consisted of
squadrons and devided companies, and no
mans endevo
r
w
ch
was muche more eminent
then other. And as for leaders in
e filde,
and principal officers, there are scarcely any in
e states Army, but suche as Count Maurice doth
depute for
e time. Only
Monsieur
de Fauma
M
o
s
r
de Fauma
governo
r
of
Hoesden
hath a permanent office, being
General of
e Artillerie
, and otherwise a gentle-
man of singular experience. Heere is also
Mons
r
de Grise
Commissary general of
e victuals
.
But no mans advise is more respected and folo-
S
r
Francis Ver
wed then
S
r
Francis Veres
, who is commonly used
by
e Count as
Mareschall of
e fielde, and
doth content
[.]
the contrey exceedingly for his
carefulnes in all thinges, aswell for direction
as execution. Being come but
newly to
e Hage, where
e Councel of state is re-
Matruit
turned againe, I have spoken
with Matruit
e
fol.297v
Matruit
e stat
Comis
s
States Commissary
, upon
whom
S
r
Edward
N
orreis doth
relie for making answear in his behalf to all
their imputations. I knowe
e
party very well,
to be a man of good discretion, and I knowe his
affection to o
r
nation in general
and to S
r
Edward
in particular
, to be more then ordinary. For w
ch
I see not howe
e Governo
r
could have sent a
fitter for his purpose: albeit he was sent for by
e states of Zeland, upon occasion of other
buisnes
.
It is perforce in these affaires,
at I must be
plainer then I would be willingly, if her Ma
tie
might be otherwise effectually served.
The forsaid
Commissary
hath bin one of
e chiefest,
at hath
from time to time informed this Councel of those
abuses of
e Governo
r
, being bound thereunto
by
his office and othe, and
not concealing from
e
Governor his proceeding
ly
so roundly. Never-
theles though he dealt in
at order for discharge of
his duty, yet I finde him very ready, to accom-
pany his c
o
plaintes
w
t
his best construction, and
to doe any good office, to make a quiet compo-
a C
o
positi
o
betw
e
e stat
and
S
r
Edward Norris
sition between
e states and
e Governo
r
. But
his travail therein can not greatly steede the
Governo
r
. For
e states are persuaded that
all his letters and offers to her Ma
tie
and to them,
are but mere
excuses and cunning devises
,
tending to no other, but to winne a litle time, w
ch
bringes a great deale of gaine, in those exacti
o
s
and profits
at he reapeth continually by usur-
great exacti
o
s
pation upon
e contrey. For at this very
present they have intelligence from ostend,
at
those of
Bridges
have presented him w
t
12
12 silv
r
Cupps
silver cuppes
, w
ch
he hath receaved, for
e confir-
mation of their entercourse. And this is certi-
new accusat
ti
o
s
fied hither w
t
an other long list of newe accusati
o
s.
fol.298r
I can not say upon certaintie, that every thing is
true, that hath bin heeretofore, or is nowe imputed
to him (albeit I can not yet in any thing con
jure
e informers of a wrongfull report) but of
this I am assured, that
e
greatest pointes of im-
portance are very maniest and true, of those
that were comprised in this Councels letters to
her Hig
nes
. Moreover there is a fresher
a new accusa
ti
o
accusation then any of those former, that is newly
sent hither from
e
states of Zeland
to
e Gene-
rall states, but not imparted as yet to
e Coun-
cel of state. For w
ch
I can not yet certifie, w
at
is written in particular: but in general I heare
that
e states of Zeland understanding
at one
Pet
r
Cortyken
a Greffier
Peter Cortiken Greffier du Franc
, w
ch
is one of
e
4 members of
Flanders
had special accesse and
conference in secret w
t
e Governo
r
of ostend,
and from him had recourse to
e D. of
Parma
,
going often in and out, w
t
great offense to all
e
contrey, to knowe w
at
practise was in hand, laid
Cortyk
e
tak
e
p
r
soner
waite for
e said Cortiken,
and
tooke him prisoner
upon
e way, and brought him to
Middlebourgh
.
where they finde by his c
o
fession, that his treaty
w
t
e Governo
r
was to contrive a peace between
a peace
her Ma
tie
and
e Enemie, the Governo
r
under-
taking to persuade w
t
her Hig
nes
, and
e Greffier
mising to worke
e Duke therunto. And this
they say, he hath declared w
t
every speciall
circumstance: w
ch
when it comes unto my handes,
I will send unto yo
r
L. Howsoever this
mater hath bin
handled by
e Governo
r
, I see it doth
distemper this people not a litle. All that I doe
feare is lest
e troblesome fire of their wonted
jalousies and diffidences, w
ch
was never quenched
thorowly, albeit nowe of late it was not muche to
be perceaved, will kindle nowe a freshe, and
cause her Ma
ties
servants,
at are heere in these
fol.298v
contreis to become more unprofitable, then they
might be otherwise. For I am almost out of hope,
that they will ever keepe any perfitte correspond
e
ce,
w
t
those they dare not trust. I knowe this
mater er be long will be bitterly proposed, and w
at
answear I should make, I am altogether doutfull,
being ignorant, as I am, howe
e Governo
r
hath pro-
ceeded, and w
t
w
at
intelligence from home. But
for me there shall be nothing heere omitted, whereby
any oversight wherew
t
he may be charged, may
be ether coloured, or excused, or construed to the
best. For many important causes, as of late I
have written in a letter to yo
r
L. so nowe againe
I am to signifie, that for
e good conduction of
these affaires of her Hig
nes
there is nothing more
expedient, then that suche as
are
heere of her Ma
ties
mi-
nisters, should impart their dealing in some degree,
w
t
him
at is heere of her Hig
nes
Councel.
For
in all suche occasions, as are offered nowe, it is
commonly to me that they addresse their first
complaintes. And what credit I can have, to seeme
to knowe nothing, or to heare
at I would not, and
yet be forced to excuse it, I leave to yo
r
L. to
consider. Where I certified yo
r
L.
that
e states of Zeland were resolved to take
some course among themselves, to redresse those
disorders committed by
e Governor, I doe
learne
by Matruit, that they were once
deter-
mined, (though he knowe not at this p
nt
howe
they are disposed) to prohibit
e carriage of any
victuals to Ostend
, w
t
out
e
paieng of Licent
mony, w
ch
is only paied for victuals to
e Enemie.
And that in regard
at
e Governo
r
himself doth
traffique, and send those victuals to
e Enemie
that come out of Zeland. As yo
r
L.
doth signifie,
e states of Zeland have bin ear-
nestly bent, to decay
e contributions of
e contrey
fol.299r
of Flanders. But is is ordened by
e General
states, that they shall be continued w
t
sufficient
provisoes to meete w
t
all inconveniences, w
ch
those of Zeland can pretend. In that
yo
r
L. doth suppose that
Holland
and
Zeland
are but coldly inclined, to extend their boundes
in Flanders, I can assure yo
w
, that
e enter-
prise intended upon
e land
of Waes, wherof I
made mention in my last from
Arnham,
is at
e special moti
o
of those of Zeland. And they
would willingly of themselves, that
e Provinces
would concurre to assaile
e Enemie in those
quarters. But they of
Frise,
Guelders
and
overissel,
and likewise
Utrecht,
have bin al-
waies very vehement in opposing against it,
refusing flatly to send any forces
fo
so farre
from their Provinces, whereby
e Enemie might
be moved to take them unprovided. For
though they knowe
at in Flanders,
e losse of any
place of good account might annoy
e Enemie
very mightily, yet they thinke on
e other side,
at
e assurance of their state, and
e custody of
that w
ch
they have in possession, is more to be
respected, then
e adding more unto it, by
taking from
e Enemie. Nowe
at
Deventer
and
Zutphen
are recovered againe, if
Nieu-
meghen
also could be gotten
,
e most part of
these contreis should stand in good securitie,
and there could be no excuse, for not imploieng
their forces to
e winning of other places.
The Enemie, we doe heare, is still
in those partes, w
ch
I mentioned last unto yo
w
.
But
e bruite is very constant of his going for
France,
and that he leaveth no part of his forces
behinde. Whiche is also confirmed, by letters
from
Brussels:
from whens they write, that
e
states have condescended to raise 2 regiments
fol.299v
19 Au
g
91
upon their owne proper charges, to defend
e contrey
in
e absence of
e Duke. Count Maurice
hath letters this day, that
e D. of Parma is gone
e D. of parma
at
Namur
to Namures
, and that
e Princes of Germany have
taken
suche
order in their several territories, as his
levies of horse will hardly gette unto him.
S
r
Francis Vere is appointed w
t
some 10 or 11 cor-
S
r
Francis Vere
sent to l
y
gh
e
nets of horse to marche towardes
Linghen
by the
Countie of
Benthem
, to spoile
e contrey people, and
as advantages are offered, to deale w
t
those troupes
of
e Enemie
at lie scattered in those quarters.
There be divers difficulties moved in the
Hulst
enterprise of
Hulst
, w
ch
require good informati
o
,
before
e action be attempted. To that effect
there are men imploied, and we expect every houre
w
at
word they will bring: w
ch
I will signifie to
yo
r
L. W
t
e first opportunitie.
And so I
take my humble leave. At
e Hage.
Au
g
19 1591
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
I have answeared nothing
to yo
r
L. about yo
r
motion for
e states
to depute some person to joine w
t
M
r
Gilpin
, for examining their c
o
plaintes,
before
e Governo
r
in ostend.
For truly maters are so cleere,
that there needes no verificati
o
,
and they, I am certaine, will
never hearken to my motion.
But I will consider w
at
other course may be best, and,
if I can, effect it otherwise,
that yo
r
L. doth require.
